title: AB 921
content:
The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts the following: Section 7519.1 is added to the Business and Professions Code, establishing a Private Investigator Disciplinary Review Committee appointed by the Governor. The committee consists of three licensed private investigators and two public members, meeting every 60 days. Members are paid per diem and travel expenses, serving a four-year term starting July 1, 2017. The Private Investigator Disciplinary Review Committee, established by the State of California, has the authority to review and make decisions on appeals related to fines, license denials, suspensions, and revocations issued by the bureau. The committee may also grant probationary licenses. This section of the Business and Professions Code will be effective on July 1, 2017. Effective July 1, 2017, licensed individuals can appeal fines or license actions to the Private Investigator Disciplinary Review Committee within 30 days in writing. Following review by the committee, the appellant will be notified in writing within 30 days of the decision. If the appellant disagrees, they can request a hearing within 30 days of the committee's decision. If no hearing is requested, the committee's decision becomes final. A licensed person can request a hearing to contest fines or appeal license decisions. The request must be made in writing within 30 days of the committee's decision. The Private Investigator Disciplinary Review Committee must receive all evidence before hearing an appeal. This section becomes effective on July 1, 2017. Section 7525.1 of the Business and Professions Code, effective July 1, 2017, requires a verified application with the applicant's full name, business address, intended business name, nature of business, and experience qualifications. To apply for a license, the applicant must provide a verified statement of experience qualifications and personal identification form with a recent photograph and fingerprints for a background check. The bureau may charge a fee of up to $3 for processing fingerprint cards, excluding electronic submissions. Applicants must list all names used in the past 10 years and declare personal involvement in the business for license application. If another manager will be in charge, their verification is required. (g) If applicants for a license are copartners, the application must include the true names and addresses of all partners, the name of the partner in charge of the business, and any other names used in the past 10 years. If a qualified manager will be in charge, all partners must sign the application. If another person will be in charge, that person and all partners or the qualified manager must sign the application under penalty of perjury. If the applicant for a license is a corporation, the application must include the names and addresses of key corporate officers and the designated person in charge of the business. The application must be signed by an authorized officer and the qualified manager under penalty of perjury. (i) For a limited liability company applicant, the application must include the names and addresses of managing members and other active officers, along with the designated person in charge of the business. A copy of the articles of organization may be requested. The application must be signed by an authorized member under penalty of perjury.
(j) Additional information, evidence, statements, or documents as required by the director.
(k) Optional provision of a valid email address. SEC. 6. Section 7525.1 of the Business and Professions Code requires a verified application with the applicant's full name, business address, intended business name, nature of business, and experience qualifications. Optional provision of a valid email address is allowed. This section is effective until January 1, 2018, unless extended or deleted by a later statute. A verified statement of experience qualifications and personal identification requirements, including fingerprints and background check, are necessary for individuals applying for a license. The bureau may charge a fee of up to $3 for processing fingerprint cards for license applicants. Applicants must list all names used in the past 10 years and declare personal involvement in the business. If another manager will be in charge, their information must also be provided and signed under penalty of perjury. (g) If the applicants for a license are copartners, the application must include the true names and addresses of all partners, the name of the partner in charge of the business, and any other names used in the past 10 years. If a qualified manager will be in charge, all partners must sign the application under penalty of perjury. If another person will be in charge, they must also sign the application along with all partners or the qualified manager. The application for a license requires the true names and addresses of key corporate officers, a designated person in charge, and any other necessary information as requested by the director. A valid email address may also be provided at the applicant's discretion. This section will be effective from January 1, 2018. Section 7541 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require applicants for a private investigator license to have at least three years of experience in investigation work, with specific requirements for those with a law degree or related education. Experience must be verified by written certifications from employers or qualified managers. Only an employer, qualified manager, or designated agent can certify experience for private investigator license applicants. The term "employer" refers to those who regularly withheld income taxes for the individual, while a "qualified manager" is someone who has met specific qualifications and directly supervised the applicant's work. An employer or qualified manager must respond within 30 days to an applicant's request for work experience certifications. If the applicant cannot obtain the response, the director may require the licensee to provide relevant employment records for evaluation. Section 7541.1 of the Business and Professions Code is amended. Section 7541.1 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to limit experience for private investigator licensure exam to activities related to investigations, performed by specific individuals such as law enforcement officers, military police, insurance adjusters, licensed private investigators, or those managed by a qualified manager. Persons employed by repossessors licensed for skip tracing, arson investigators in public agencies, and investigators in public defender offices are exempt from certain requirements. Possession of an associate of arts degree in relevant fields can also count towards experience for investigative activities. The activities that do not count as acts of investigation for licensure experience include serving legal process, searching for heirs using public records, transporting persons in law enforcement custody, providing security to a court, debt collection after locating the debtor, and repossession of property after identification. The director may determine the percentage of experience an applicant is entitled to credit for both qualifying and non-qualifying activities in their employment.
